abstract: John W. Keker, lawyer for the former Citigroup employee accused of misleading investors, offered what will forever be known in the securities field as the “Where’s Waldo?” defense by arguing that his client should not be the only one held responsible because he was a minor player in a much larger process.
snippet: John W. Keker, lawyer for the former Citigroup employee accused of misleading investors, offered what will forever be known in the securities field as the “Where’s Waldo?” defense by arguing that his client should not be the only one held responsi...
lead_paragraph: When you are unable to win a prize playing a carnival game, the attendant usually says, “Better luck next time!” as you pony up for another round. That is pretty much what a federal jury told the Securities and Exchange Commission when it urged the government to continue to pursue financial fraud cases involving Wall Street while finding the agency had not proven that a former Citigroup banker, Brian H. Stoker, had violated securities laws.

headline.main: S.E.C. Gets Encouragement, but Needs Something More
